Building Missile Defense May Start Arms Race American intelligence officials are warning that building a limited national missile defense could set off a cold-war-style arms race between China, India and Pakistan, administration officials say, as President Clinton nears a decision on whether to build such a system.
INTERNATIONAL

Building Missile Defense May Start Arms Race American intelligence officials are warning that building a limited national missile defense could set off a cold-war-style arms race between China, India and Pakistan, administration officials say, as President Clinton nears a decision on whether to build such a system.

Ulster Set for Local Rule Northern Ireland's largest Protestant party voted by a narrow margin to return to a power-sharing administration with their Catholic rivals in Sinn Fein, the political representatives of the Irish Republican Army, meaning that governing of the province will shift to Belfast in days.

Iran's New Parliament Opens Iran's new reformer-dominated parliament opened in Tehran, the first since the Islamic revolution to include a majority of members who appear eager and ready to challenge the conservative clergy's control.

Presidential Debate in Mexico In a televised debate with two rivals, Vicente Fox Quesada, the leading opposition presidential candidate in Mexico, gave a vigorous performance that helped him recover from embarrassing mistakes last week.
Low Turnout at Belgrade Rally About 10,000 people attended an anti-government rally, a relatively low turnout reflecting popular disappointment with the leaders of the political opposition.
NATIONAL

Gore Faults Bush Plan On Arms Cuts and Defense Vice President Al Gore, speaking at the United States Military Academy, criticized Gov. George W. Bush's support for a national missile defense system along with a possible one-sided reduction in American nuclear warheads.

Where Beauty Reigns Supreme South Beach, the southernmost tip of the city of Miami Beach, is utterly absorbed by beauty, peopled with fashion models and dreamers and others who just like moving about a place where bartenders pose like Grecian statues and cafe hostesses are achingly lovely.

Bennington College in Turmoil Bennington College is once again in turmoil with dissident and dismissed faculty members casting Dr. Elizabeth Coleman, the president, as a dictatorial figure who crushes any criticism. Two trustees have resigned.

Labor Split by China Trade Vote The labor movement is badly divided on political strategy after last week's vote in favor of the China trade bill, which labor opposed. Some union leaders and Democratic consultants say this split could set back the party's electoral chances.

Drivers Pay Record Gas Prices Gasoline prices have soared to the highest levels of the year in many parts of the nation, after falling a good bit in the wake of a decision by the petroleum-exporting countries in March to increase oil production.
NEW YORK/REGION

Giuliani Departure Changes Assumptions in Senate Race The New York Senate race has been transformed from a battle over a few undecided voters into a broad and complex contest. Voting blocs and geographical preferences that had seemed fixed are suddenly up for grabs after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's departure, strategists say.

New Rent Rules Contested There is a new battlefront between tenants and landlords: 200 pages of legalese drafted by New York State officials to rewrite the rent regulations that cover 2.4 million residents, most of them in New York City.

Fear of Crime Remains Low Despite a number of recent ghoulish crimes making the news in New York, it is difficult to catch many people -- especially affluent people -- in the act of worrying about the return of crime to where they live.
